speaker: Rob
text: I’m Rob. Welcome to 6 Minute English – we’ve got a sweet topic today, and six tempting items of vocabulary.

speaker: Neil
text: Hello, I’m Neil. And we’re going to be talking about sugar – which many of us find tempting. But how much is too much, Rob?

speaker: have a sweet tooth
text: I don’t know, Neil, but hopefully we’ll be finding that out. I must admit though – I have a sweet tooth – and that means I like sugary things!

speaker: Neil
text: Me too. But something I’m always seeing in the news these days is that we’re eating too much sugar. And one important factor is that sugars are sometimes hidden in processed foods.

speaker: Processed
text: Processed food is any food that has been changed in some way – by freezing it or putting it in tins – or by combining foods or adding chemicals. In fact, some of the sugars we eat are hidden in food that we think of as healthy. Such as yoghurts, low fat snacks, and fruit drinks.

speaker: Neil
text: Do you check the information on the back of food packets, Rob? – To see what’s in them?

speaker: Rob
text: Yes, I do. But it can be very confusing – there’s so much information. And I’m not always sure how much of a certain thing is bad.

speaker: Neil
text: Well, that brings me onto today’s quiz question. Can you tell me, if a food contains 5% total sugars per 100g, is it…

speaker: Neil
text: a) high in sugar,

speaker: Neil
text: b) low in sugar or

speaker: Neil
text: c) somewhere in the middle?

speaker: Rob
text: I’ll say low, Neil.

speaker: Neil
text: OK. Well, we'll find out later. Some food products have colour coding on the packaging to help you understand the information, don’t they? – red for high levels of sugar, salt or fat– orange for medium, and green for low.

speaker: at a glance
text: That sounds helpful. Then you can see at a glance what’s good or bad for you.

speaker: Neil
text: At a glance means with a quick look. OK, let’s listen now to BBC reporter Rajeev Gupta interviewing a man in Chester, in the UK. He’s asking him to guess how much sugar there is in a pot of fat-free yoghurt.

speaker: INSERT
text: Rajeev Gupta, reporter interviewing a man in Chester

speaker: Reporter:
text: Reporter: I've actually got a pot of yoghurt in front of me. This says 'fat-free' on it and it's been marketed as being quite healthy. If I was to say how much sugar is in here, what would you say as… say is the quantity of the tub?

speaker: Interviewee:
text: Interviewee: I’d probably think maybe a couple of teaspoonfuls, you know, it’s quite surprising how much is sugars in all these products, isn’t there?

speaker: Reporter:
text: Reporter: Well, there’s about a third of this yoghurt pot is actually sugar.

speaker: Interviewee:
text: Interviewee: To be honest, that’s quite amazing, that. I would never have thought a third of that would have been sugar just by looking at it. And it does say it’s fat-free.

speaker: fat-free
text: So the yoghurt is fat-free, which means it doesn’t contain any fat. And the man guessed there might be two teaspoons of sugar in the yoghurt.

speaker: Rob
text: That’s right. And if something is sugar-free then it doesn’t contain any sugar. But in this case, a third of the yoghurt’s content was sugar. That, to me, sounds like an awful lot – even for someone with a sweet tooth like me!

speaker: Neil
text: OK, well, let’s listen to Dr Gunter Kuhnle. He’s a Nutritional Biochemist at Reading University.

speaker: Dr Gunter Kuhnle, nutritional biochemist at Reading University, UK
text: One problem we see – nutritionists – is sort of this focusing on any individual foods – at one time it was that fat has to be avoided at all costs, now it seems to go towards sugar and sugar is demonised and people link it to drugs and so on. I think this is the wrong way forward. Individuals, yes, you should have a balanced diet. It is important also to enjoy your food and not do this extreme focusing on one side or one aspect and individual nutrients.

speaker: avoid something at all costsdemonise
text: So if you avoid something at all costs you do everything you can to avoid it. And demonise means to make someone or something seem very bad.

speaker: Neil
text: Dr Kuhnle thinks that totally cutting out one type of food like this – whether it’s fat or sugar – is wrong. He thinks we should eat a balanced diet – and enjoy our food.

speaker: Rob
text: That sounds very sensible. Now, how about telling us the answer to today’s quiz question, Neil?

speaker: Neil
text: Thanks for reminding me, Rob. I asked: if food contains 5% total sugars per 100g, is it… a) high in sugar, b) low in sugar or c) somewhere in the middle? You said low… and you were… right! Well done!

speaker: Rob
text: Thank you.

speaker: Neil
text: If foods contain more than 22.5% total sugars per 100g they are classified as high.

speaker: Rob
text: And I guess that between 5 and 22.5% they are somewhere in the middle.

speaker: Neil
text: Correct! OK, shall we go over the words we heard today?

speaker: Rob
text: Yep. First up – if you have a ‘sweet tooth’ it means you like sugary things. For example, ‘My little nephew has a sweet tooth. He eats far too many biscuits and sweets.’

speaker: Neil
text: His dentist won’t be pleased! Number two – ‘processed food’ is any food that has been changed in some way – by freezing it or putting it in tins – or by combining foods or adding chemicals.

speaker: Rob
text: For example, ‘The meat in sausages is highly processed.’

speaker: Neil
text: Oh dear, I didn’t know that. I’m a big fan of sausages!

speaker: Rob
text: Number three – ‘at a glance’ – means with a quick look.

speaker: Neil
text: For example, 'I could tell at a glance that I wouldn’t like the food at that restaurant.’

speaker: Rob
text: ‘Fat-free’ means without any fat in it. For example, ‘I bought this yoghurt because it says fat-free on the label.’

speaker: Neil
text: Aha – but did you realise that a third of it was sugar! Moving on – If you avoid something‘at all costs’ you do everything you can to avoid it. For example, ‘I wanted to win the game at all costs.’

speaker: Rob
text: I didn’t know you were so competitive, Neil! And finally – ‘demonise’ – means to make someone or something seem very bad.

speaker: Neil
text: ‘Politicians shouldn’t demonise their opponents.’

speaker: Rob
text: They often do though, don’t they? OK. Well, that’s all we have time for on today’s show. But please check out our Instagram, Twitter, Facebook and YouTube pages.
